comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: "Milchzucker" is German for lactose (milk sugar.) I guess that's what accounts for the milk bottles in the drawing, but what could be the significance of the bird?

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content:
whyaduck:

Thanks for the comment!  Lactose, or milk sugar, was (and still is) used to make infant formula, so that likely explains the presence of the stork and the baby bottles on this packaging.  We'll add a bit more information to the descriptive data and reload it to Flickr.

comment.author: 80278590@N00
comment._content: The bird is a stork, and the buildings look suspiciously like baby bottles. "Reiner" seems to mean pure, and perhaps Chemilch is the product name? Is this perhaps formula for an infant?

comment.author: 82195171@N00
comment._content: It's "Chemisch reiner..." and it just means "chemically pure milk sugar".
